image.altText: A fire burns over a hill. It is night,  and the sky is black with the fire and smoke red and orange.

items.synopsis: Authorities predict 80 per cent of the Northern Territory will burn from bushfires by March in a once-in-a-decade event.

title.children: NT authorities say this bushfire season will be the worst in a decade. Here's why

image.altText: The tail of a Jetstar aircraft showing its name an livery

items.synopsis: The airline confirms it has cancelled flights between Darwin and Denpasar for three weeks in October due to runway upgrades at Darwin Airport.

title.children: 'Disappointing and frustrating': Jetstar cancels October flights between Darwin and Bali

image.altText: Composite image of two women and two men, all smiling.

items.synopsis: The woman who cooked a meal that is believed to have contained poisonous mushrooms and led to the deaths of three people gives a lengthy written statement to police detailing her account of what happened, and revealing she was hospitalised after the incident.

title.children: Woman who cooked suspected poisoned meal details where she bought mushrooms from

image.altText: Lockie

items.synopsis: Thousands of babies who've been exposed to their mother's drug use are born in Australia every year. Help is difficult to find.

title.children: Terrianne has used ice throughout pregnancies. This time was different

image.altText: Mark Latham speaks with Pauline Hanson in the background.

items.synopsis: One Nation MP Mark Latham says he was removed from the party "without consultation or due process".

title.children: Mark Latham dumped by Pauline Hanson as One Nation's NSW leader

image.altText: Two young boys stand out the front of the youth centre.

items.synopsis: In Tennant Creek, where shopfronts are graffitied or boarded up, the town's youth centre stands out as shiny and new — but it's never opened its doors.

title.children: These kids say a youth centre will make a big difference to their lives. One sits empty in their town

image.altText: Headshot of Epidemiologist Mary-Louise McLaws.

items.synopsis: The scientific community pays tribute to the calm, warm epidemiologist who led Australia during the COVID-19 pandemic who some say was more respected than a head of state.

title.children: 'Authoritative but thoughtful': Leading scientists pay tribute to pandemic epidemiologist Mary-Louise McLaws

image.altText: Side by side photos of business logos for accounting firms Deloitte, PwC, KPMG and EY

items.synopsis: The infiltration of EY, Deloitte, KPMG and PwC in government departments has been well documented. What is less well known is their role in the private sector, where experts fear a sleeper issue could trigger a corporate collapse, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: How a sleeper issue inside the big four accounting giants could topple the economy

image.altText: A skiier in a yellow jacket skis down a steep slope

items.synopsis: Discretionary spending is money you don't need to spend to keep yourself fed, housed and clothed. What's happening at alpine resorts — remote and relatively expensive — tells us about an important shift in the Australian economy.

title.children: Australians are reducing their spending as the cost of living soars. But that doesn't mean they're making rational choices

image.altText: Police detectives in bushland searching the ground.

items.synopsis: Police have charged a teenager with murder after a 16-year-old-boy was fatally stabbed north of Coffs Harbour in New South Wales last night.

title.children: Community in shock as police charge teenager with murder over alleged Coffs Harbour stabbing

image.altText: young boy in blue button up shirt with mullet pouts

items.synopsis: Caleb Puttyfoot, 16, is being remembered as a "truly great person" and a proud older brother after he succumbed to injuries sustained when he was allegedly struck by a four-wheel drive.

title.children: Tributes for teen who 'fought so hard' after alleged hit and run

image.altText: A youth walks down a street in Roebourne alongside a metal fence.

items.synopsis: Once synonymous with alcohol abuse and social malaise, Roebourne is a town in recovery. But traditional owners lament what they say are the divisions caused by a mining giant.

title.children: 'Triumph and tragedy' of town divided in fight against mining giant

image.altText: A composite image of a woman wearing a t-shirt that says "love" before and after breast reduction surgery.

items.synopsis: Surgery to decrease bra cup sizes is on the increase in Australia. Helen Stojanovski just wishes she'd booked her surgery sooner.

title.children: The number of Aussies getting breast reductions has tripled in three years. Helen is one of them

image.altText: A composite image of Sam Kerr and Michele Bullock

items.synopsis: From the Matildas to some of the most important appointments in the country, Australian women are beginning to receive the acknowledgement and opportunities at the top of their fields that unquestionably until now have been denied, writes John Lyons.

title.children: What Sam Kerr and new RBA governor Michele Bullock have in common

image.altText: Side by side images of a resort town. Left it is green and has boats in the water, on the right brown and burned down, no boats.

items.synopsis: Aerial footage and satellite images show how devastating the fires that engulfed the Hawaiian island of Maui have been, as crews continue searching for survivors.

title.children: Lahaina was once a lush green resort town, it's now been reduced to ash and rubble

image.altText: People pray in church on their knees

items.synopsis: A crowd-sourced online database has been launched to find missing individuals as friends and family mourn those killed in the devastating Hawaiian wildfires.

title.children: 'God took a really good man': Friends heartbroken over those dead in Maui blaze

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

items.synopsis: The big miners are leading the ASX lower as a major Chinese developer suspends trading in 11 of its bonds amid a debt crisis. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Chinese developer woes weigh on Aussie dollar, ASX, despite results boost for JB Hi-Fi

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Jumping in to bring you the closing number from the local session and let's just say we've ended on a down note, but it could've been worse. The ASX 200 closed down by 0.9 per cent. But looking around the region, other markets fared even worse— Tokyo's Nikkei closed more than 1 per cent lower while stocks in Hong Kong are down more than 2 per cent. Locally, it was the mining stocks that really weighed on the market. At some points the afternoon, the ASX 300 Metals & Mining index was down as much as 2 per cent, to its lowest in more than a month. Worries around the health of China's economy, particularly the property sector, a key source of demand for Australian resources, fueled the selling. Traders are awaiting retail sales and industrial production data out of China tomorrow, with concerns it could disappoint, while property developer Country Garden suspended trading in its onshore bonds. On the local share market, 154 of the top 200 stocks ended in the red, with only two sectors posting modest gains — technology and energy. Financials were hit hard, with Bendigo and Adelaide Bank shares dropping 2.9 per cent after its profit result didn't receive a good reception. Here are the biggest individual stock moves on the benchmark index this session: Bottom 5 Syrah Resources (-6.9%) Elders (-6.1%) Pilbara Minerals (-6%) Allkem (-3.9%) Sayona Mining (-3.7%) Top 5 Lake Resources (+7.7%) Carsales (+7%) Sims (+4%) Imugene (+3.4%) Life360 (+3%) The Australian dollar has also lost ground, trading below 64.8 US cents.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX dragged down as Hong Kong stocks tumble

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Bendigo and Adelaide Bank has seen its shares sold down 2.9% to $8.925 over the first four hours of the trading day after posting a 1.8% increase in statutory net profit to $497 million. The bank's preferred measure of cash profit — which excludes one-offs such as a software writedown and restructuring costs — was up a healthier 15.3% to $576.9 million. Like its big four rivals, Bendigo and Adelaide enjoyed a healthy increase in its net interest margin (NIM) — the gap between what the bank pays to borrow money and the rates it lends it out at. Its NIM rose 0.2 of a percentage point to 1.94%, which was still lagging larger rivals such as CBA, which last week reported a 0.17 percentage point increase in NIM to 2.07%. Unlike CBA, which reported a decrease in NIM over the second half, Bendigo and Adelaide said it has increase its NIM to 1.98% over that period amid reduced competition in the home loan market, resulting in smaller customer discounts. The bank boasted an increase of 0.9 of a percentage point on its return on equity (ROE), a key measure of profitability, to 8.62%. This compares to an ROE for the Commonwealth Bank of around 14% last financial year. The bank said it is "not seeing material signs of borrower distress" and there was a reduction in bad debts over the latest half year to June 30.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Bendigo and Adelaide Bank shares sold down after 1.8% profit growth

The bank's preferred measure of

up a healthier 15.3% to $576.9 million
Like its big four rivals,
Bendigo and Adelaide enjoyed a healthy increase in its net interest margin (NIM)
— the gap between what the bank pays to borrow money and the rates it lends it out at.
Its
NIM rose 0.2 of a percentage point to 1.94%
, which was still lagging larger rivals such as CBA, which last week reported a 0.17 percentage point increase in NIM to 2.07%.

Unlike CBA, which reported a decrease in NIM over the second half, Bendigo and Adelaide said it has increase its NIM to 1.98% over that period amid reduced competition in the home loan market, resulting in smaller customer discounts.
The bank boasted an increase of
0.9 of a percentage point on its return on equity (ROE)
, a key measure of profitability, to 8.62%.
This compares to an ROE for the Commonwealth Bank of around 14% last financial year.
The bank said it is
"not seeing material signs of borrower distress"
and there was a reduction in bad debts over the latest half year to June 30.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's the latest from financial news service Reuters on the debt woes afflicting Country Garden, one of China's main real estate developers: Chinese property giant Country Garden's shares plunged to fresh record low on Monday, while its offshore bonds were also pressured after its onshore paper was suspended from trading as its debt problems deepened. Shares of Country Garden shed more than 15% to HK$0.83 in morning trading, dragging down the Hang Seng Mainland Properties Index, which dropped 4.6%. The stock has lost nearly 50% so far this month. Country Garden's offshore bonds also eased, with a few trading at the lower end of 6 cents on the dollar. Its January 2031 bond traded at 6.071 cents as at 0228 GMT, according to data by Duration Finance. In separate filings during the weekend, the firm said it would suspend trading in 11 of its onshore bonds from Monday, and their resumption of trading would be determined at a later date. The move followed reports on Friday that the company was heading for a debt restructuring, after it missed payments of two dollar bond coupons due on Aug. 6 totalling $22.5 million. Six cents in the dollar on a bond implies an extremely low degree of confidence that investors will get anything back on their loans to Country Garden. Definitely one to watch, along with Evergrande and a raft of other Chinese developers that are in deep financial bother.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Chinese developer Country Garden's shares hit fresh low, some bonds at 6 cents on the dollar

children.content: Here's the latest from financial news service Reuters on the debt woes afflicting
Country Garden
, one of China's main real estate developers:

Chinese property giant Country Garden's shares plunged to fresh record low on Monday, while its offshore bonds were also pressured after its onshore paper was suspended from trading as its debt problems deepened.
Shares of Country Garden shed more than 15% to HK$0.83
in morning trading, dragging down the Hang Seng Mainland Properties Index, which dropped 4.6%.
The stock has lost nearly 50% so far this month.
Country Garden's offshore bonds also eased
, with a few trading at the lower end of 6 cents on the dollar.
Its January 2031 bond traded at 6.071 cents
as at 0228 GMT, according to data by Duration Finance.
In separate filings during the weekend,
the firm said it would suspend trading in 11 of its onshore bonds
from Monday, and their resumption of trading would be determined at a later date.
The move followed reports on Friday that the company was
heading for a debt restructuring
, after it
missed payments of two dollar bond coupons
due on Aug. 6 totalling $22.5 million.
Six cents in the dollar on a bond implies an
extremely low degree of confidence that investors will get anything back
on their loans to Country Garden.
Definitely one to watch, along with
Evergrande
and a raft of other Chinese developers that are in deep financial bother.

image.altText: A tree painted with words build the road in silver paint.

items.synopsis: The latest protest in a long-running dispute over the protection of culturally significant trees in western Victoria earmarked for demolition to make way for a highway upgrade have ramped up after the vandalism of a birthing tree.

title.children: 'Like a death in the family': Sacred Aboriginal birthing tree vandalised as highway upgrade dispute ramps up

image.altText: A Pacific walrus pup rests his head on the lap of a staff member

items.synopsis: A rare Pacific walrus calf that drew international attention for requiring "round-the-clock cuddling" treatment has died after it developed a number of health complications.

title.children: 'Heartbroken': Rescued walrus calf who required 'round-the-clock cuddles' dies

image.altText: Pink stands on stage holding a mic stand as she glitters in a pink bodysuit and studded black leather jacket.

items.synopsis: For the first time in four years, the Townsville Stadium will host a major music artist, with international superstar P!nk announcing a surprise March show at the venue.

title.children: P!nk to perform at Townsville stadium, breaking four-year concert drought at $300m venue

image.altText: Graham Ashton stands behind Peter Malinauskas.

items.synopsis: Former Victorian police commissioner Graham Ashton will lead an inquiry into South Australia's greyhound racing industry, that was sparked by an ABC report of apparent abuse in the industry.

title.children: Former police commissioner to lead SA greyhound racing industry inquiry

image.altText: Nicole Hammat holds a framed photograph of her son Khye smiling

items.synopsis: After seeing how quickly her son Khye succumbed to the disease, Nicole Hammat wants young people to be more aware of meningococcal and is pleading for the B strain vaccine to be made accessible to more people.

title.children: Mother's plea for meningococcal B vaccine to be made more accessible as cases continue to rise

image.altText: A large curved building with the skycity logo

items.synopsis: The Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre (AUSTRAC) launched Federal Court action against SkyCity in December, alleging systemic non-compliance with anti-money laundering and counter terrorism financing laws.

title.children: Adelaide casino sets aside $45m to cover potential penalty as court case continues

image.altText: A close-up shot of a pallet of cardboard boxes being pulled by a red and black pallet jack.

items.synopsis: WA authorities discover 300,000 vapes in a Perth warehouse, along with more than 10 tonnes of illegal prescription drugs and "nangs",  in what they say is the biggest-ever bust of its kind in Australia.

title.children: More than 25 tonnes of vapes and 'nangs' found hidden in record seizure

image.altText: A generic photo of a green seedling in dirt in an egg carton, with other little seedlings around it.

items.synopsis: We heard from more than 1,000 of you who shared the little, and big, things you do to reduce your waste footprint. There were plenty of new and novel ideas for reusing and recycling, so we're tapping into the brains trust.

title.children: We asked for your waste-busting tips. Here are some of your suggestions

image.altText: An older man with a moustache wearing a white tshirt and cap, runs in a race with his hands up

items.synopsis: To run just one marathon is a massive achievement for most people — this 69-year-old has just chalked up his 100th.

title.children: It all started with a run with his brother 20 years ago. Now Michael just has finished his 100th marathon

image.altText: man with weights in gym

items.synopsis: An increasing demand for steroids in young men has been linked to a growing uptake for a needle and syringe exchange program, leading to calls for more education on the side effects.

title.children: 'You're just relying on the next gym bro': Young men desperate for safe steroid advice

image.altText: A lady with a red face following chemo treatment.

items.synopsis: A Greens senator's experience with skin cancer prompts a warning about cumulative sun exposure as skin cancer rates rise, despite the success of the Slip Slop Slap campaign for those born after 1980.

title.children: Melanoma rates dropping for younger people in Queensland, but skin cancer still on the rise

image.altText: Bruce Lehrmann looks serious, sitting wearing his glasses against a blurred background.

items.synopsis: The former Liberal Party adviser says his life is "stuffed" and he may never work again after his high-profile rape trial was abandoned.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann says he will seek 'millions' of dollars after inquiry finds prosecution was flawed

image.altText: A man holds two green apples in his hands

items.synopsis: While inflation on food has gone down according to stats from the Australian Bureau of Statistics June 2023 report, prices for things like dairy and bread remain sky high.

title.children: Food prices have risen 7.5 per cent in the last year. Here's what that looks like at the check-out
